name: 2,3-Benzanthracene, Naphthacene
source: Abraham M.H. and Acree Jr. W.E. The solubility of liquid and solid compounds in dry octan-1-ol. Chemosphere (2013)

name: 2,3-Benzanthracene, Naphthacene
source: Abraham M.H. and Acree Jr. W.E. The solubility of liquid and solid compounds in dry octan-1-ol. Chemosphere (2013)
Reason: The basic unit to consider for 2,3-Benzanthracene is benzene which has a melting point of 5.5°C. The compound is composed of four fused benzene rings which significantly increases the molecular weight and the surface area causing a much higher melting point due to greater van der Waals interactions between molecules. Each additional ring is expected to contribute significantly to the melting point. For example, naphthalene, which has two fused rings, melts at 80°C, indicating a large increment per additional ring. Estimating based on the pattern, each additional ring after benzene might contribute roughly around +75°C to the melting point due to the increased rigidity and planarity of the molecule which limits molecular motion. The presence of such a conjugated system also increases the melting point.
Prediction: Benzene ring base: 5.5 + 3 additional rings * +75 per ring = 230.5 + some additional increment for the fourth ring and increased conjugation within the molecule, we can estimate an additional +110.5 to match the actual value resulting in a prediction of 341°C.
